title-group.article-title: Minimax Approximate Solutions of Linear Boundary Value Problems

abstract.p: Define the operator $D: C''\lbrack 0, \tau \rbrack \rightarrow C\lbrack 0, \tau\rbrack$ by $D\lbrack u \rbrack = u'' - a_0 u' - a_1 u$ where $a_0, a_1 \in C\lbrack 0, \tau\rbrack$ and consider the two point boundary value problem (BVP) $D\lbrack y \rbrack(x) = a_2(x), x \in \lbrack 0, \tau\rbrack, N_0\lbrack y \rbrack = \alpha_0y(0) + \alpha_1 y'(0) = \alpha_2, N_\tau \lbrack y \rbrack = \beta_0 y(\tau) + \beta_1 y'(\tau) = \beta_2$ where $a_2 \in C\lbrack 0, \tau \rbrack, \alpha^2_0 + \alpha^2_1 \neq 0$ and $\beta^2_0 + \beta^2_1 \neq 0$. Let $\Pi_k$ denote the set of polynomials of degree at most $k$ and define the approximating set $\mathcal{P}_k = \{p \in \Pi_k: N_0 \lbrack p \rbrack = \alpha_2, N_\tau\lbrack p \rbrack = \beta_2\}$. Then for each $k \geqslant 3$ there exists $p_k \in \mathcal{P}_k$ satisfying $\|D\lbrack p_k \rbrack - a_2\| = \inf_{p\in\mathcal{P}_k}\|D\lbrack p \rbrack - a_2\| = \delta_k$, where $\| \cdot \|$ denotes the uniform norm on $C\lbrack 0, \tau \rbrack$. If the homogeneous BVP $D\lbrack y \rbrack = 0, N_0\lbrack y \rbrack = N_\tau\lbrack y \rbrack = 0$ has no nontrivial solutions, then the nonhomogeneous BVP has a unique solution $y$ and $\lim_{k\rightarrow\infty}\|p^{(i)}_k - y^{(i)}\| = 0$ for $i = 0, 1, 2$. If $X$ denotes a closed subset of $\lbrack 0, \tau \rbrack$ and $$\delta_{k,X} = \operatornamewithlimits{\inf}_{p\in\mathcal{P}_k} \operatornamewithlimits{\max}_{x\in X}|D|lbrack p \rbrack(x) - a_2(x)|,$$ then for each $\epsilon > 0$ there exists $\delta > 0$ such that $d(X) \leqslant \delta$ implies that $0 \leqslant \delta_k - \delta_{k,X} \leqslant \epsilon$, where $d(X)$ denotes the density of $X$ in $\lbrack 0, \tau \rbrack$. Several numerical examples are given.
